extendedIngredients.name: extra virgin olive oil
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 teaspoons extra virgin olive oil, divided

extendedIngredients.name: flat leaf parsley leaves
extendedIngredients.originalString: ½ cup packed fresh flat-leaf parsley leaves, chopped

extendedIngredients.name: ground pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: ½ teaspoon fresh ground pepper, divided

extendedIngredients.name: salmon fillets
extendedIngredients.originalString: 4 skinless wild salmon fillets (5 ounces each)

recipes.title: Salmon and Warm Lentil Salad

winePairing.pairingText: Fish on the menu? Try pairing with Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Grüner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Attems Ramato Pinot Grigio with a 4.4 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 14 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Attems Ramato Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: Pinot Grigio Ramato continues a tradition of the Republic of Venice, since “ramato”, or coppery, was the term referred to Pinot Grigio in contracts. A special vinification practice led to the use of this term: the must remains in contact with the skins for 24 hours and this practice gives the wine a very distinctive coppery hue. Attems Cupra Ramato boasts a rich, fruity bouquet, and opens full and weighty on the palate, with multi-faceted flavors.It is perfect when paired with fatty fish, with delicate or vegetable-based antipasti, the ideal companion to summer dishes, and is delicious as well as an aperitif.

recipes.instructions: Place slightly warm cooked lentils in a medium bowl. add ½ teaspoon salt, ¼ teaspoon pepper, 2 teaspoons olive oil, vinegar, mustard honey and stir to combine.Meanwhile, sprinkle both sides of the fish with the remaining salt and pepper. In a large skillet, heat the remaining 2 teaspoons oil over medium high heat. Add the fish and cook, turning once, for 3 to 4 minutes per side (or until the fish is opaque and flakes easily when tested with a fork).Remove from the heat and finish preparing the salad. To the lentil mixture, add the mixed green, parsley and shallot and toss gently to combine. Serve with the salmon.

steps.step: Place slightly warm cooked lentils in a medium bowl. add ½ teaspoon salt, ¼ teaspoon pepper, 2 teaspoons olive oil, vinegar, mustard honey and stir to combine.Meanwhile, sprinkle both sides of the fish with the remaining salt and pepper. In a large skillet, heat the remaining 2 teaspoons oil over medium high heat.
Add the fish and cook, turning once, for 3 to 4 minutes per side (or until the fish is opaque and flakes easily when tested with a fork).
Remove from the heat and finish preparing the salad. To the lentil mixture, add the mixed green, parsley and shallot and toss gently to combine.
